description:
Manis pentadactyla, commonly known as the Chinese pangolin, is a species of pangolin native to eastern Asia. It is a small, scaly mammal that belongs to the order Pholidota.

The Chinese pangolin is characterized by its heavily armored body, which is covered in overlapping, keratin scales. These scales serve as a protective mechanism against predators. The species has five toes on each of its feet, which is the origin of its scientific name "pentadactyla," meaning "five-fingered."

Pangolins are known for their unique foraging behavior, using their long, sticky tongues to extract ants and termites from their nests. The Chinese pangolin is primarily nocturnal and arboreal, spending much of its time in the trees. It plays an important role in the ecosystem as a predator of various insect species.

Unfortunately, the Chinese pangolin is classified as Critically Endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) due to ongoing threats such as habitat loss and illegal poaching for its meat and scales, which are used in traditional Chinese medicine. Conservation efforts are underway to protect this unique and threatened species.
